metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of airborne WiDAS mission in the Zhangye-Yingke-Huazhaizi flight zone on June 1, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of airborne WiDAS mission was obtained in the Zhangye-Yingke-Huazhaizi flight zone on Jun. 1, 2008.
     Data available for general users include Level-2C data (after geometric, radiometric and atmospheric corrections). Level-1B browse image (after intra-band matching) and Level-2B browse image (intra-band after registration). The raw data, Level-1A, and data processing parameters were filed; applications would be evaluated prior to access. Data processing started Aug. 2008 and ended Apr. 2009, and in Nov. 2009, CCD data were reprocessed to adjust radiometric calibration. 
     The raw data set included 12 flight routs, some of which were repeated. There was discrepancy about 1.4s between exposure time of CCD images at 650nm/750nm and that of 550nm/700nm. Images in different bands has been matched during pre-processing. However, in areas with large elevation changes, intra-bands match error still existed.
     The flying time of each route was as follows:

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data processing techniques used for airborne remote sensing datasets?
Feature Specification.Answer: geometric correction, radiometric calibration, atmospheric correction, Level-2C products, application approval required, processing period from August 2008 to April 2009, correction in November 2009 for CCD camera radiometric calibration

Quantification.Question: How many flight lines were recorded during the data collection process on June 1, 2008, in the 张掖-盈科-花寨子飞行区?

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the instability of airborne sensor data collection, particularly in the context of varying altitude regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The instability in airborne sensor data collection can be influenced by the condition of the instruments, as some flights had to be redone due to unstable instrument status. Additionally, there are discrepancies in imaging times between different wavelengths, such as the 650nm, 750nm, 550nm, and 700nm bands, which result in registration errors, especially in areas with significant elevation changes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on data quality when using airborne sensors with unstable instrumentation conditions during data collection?
Causal Consequence.Answer: When using airborne sensors with unstable instrumentation conditions during data collection, potential outcomes on data quality include incomplete data, missing or lacking spectral bands, and registration errors, especially in areas with significant elevation changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to conduct airborne remote sensing in the Zhangye-Yingke-Huazhaizi flight area using WiDAS sensors, and what are the objectives of processing and correcting the data collected?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of conducting airborne remote sensing in the Zhangye-Yingke-Huazhaizi flight area using WiDAS sensors is to acquire high-resolution, multispectral data that can be used for various environmental and geographical analyses. The objectives of processing and correcting the data collected include achieving geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction to ensure accuracy and reliability of the data products for further analysis. These corrections help to minimize errors due to instrument instability and environmental conditions, and they enhance the utility of the data for typical users by providing Level-2C products and visualizations in Level-1B and Level-2B formats.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps involved in the preprocessing of airborne WiDAS sensor data to ensure it is ready for user access and analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The key steps involved in the preprocessing of airborne WiDAS sensor data include geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction. The processed data is released as Level-2C products, suitable for general users, and includes geometric correction, radiometric calibration, and atmospheric correction. Level-1B (band registration) quick views and Level-2B quick views are also provided. The original Level-1A data and processing parameters are archived, requiring an application and approval to access.
